[h1]The Math Operators[/h1]

Java provides a rich set of operators to use in manipulating variables. A value used on either side of an operator is called an [b]operand[/b]. 
For example, in the expression below, the numbers 6 and 3 are operands of the plus operator: [code format="java"]int x = 6 + 3;[/code]
Java arithmetic operators: 
+ [b]addition[/b]
- [b]subtraction[/b]
* [b]multiplication[/b]
/ [b]division[/b]
% [b]modulo[/b]
[note]Arithmetic operators are used in mathematical expressions in the same way that they are used in algebraic equations.[/note]

[h1]Modulo[/h1]

The [b]modulo [/b](or remainder) math operation performs an integer division of one value by another, and returns the remainder of that division. 
The operator for the modulo operation is the percentage (%) character.
Example:[code format="java" codeId="719"]int value = 23;
int res = value % 6; // res is 5[/code]
[note]Dividing 23 by 6 returns a quotient of 3, with a remainder of 5. Thus, the value of 5 is assigned to the [b]res [/b]variable.[/note]
